How hard, when those who do not wish</br>To lend, that's lose, their books,</br>Are snared by anglers — folks that fish</br>With literary hooks;
Who call and take some favourite tome,</br>But never read it through;</br>They thus complete their set at home,</br>By making one at you.
Behold the book-shelf of a dunce</br>Who borrows — never lends;</br>Yon work, in twenty volumes, once</br>Belonged to twenty friends.
New tales and novels you may shut</br>From view — 'tis all in vain;</br>They're gone — and though the leaves are "cut,"</br>They never "come again."
For pamphlets lent I look around,</br>For tracts my tears are spilt;</br>But when they take a book that's bound,</br>'Tis surely extra-guilt.
A circulating library</br>Is mine — my birds are flown;</br>There's one odd volume left, to be</br>Like all the rest, a-lone.
I, of my "Spencer" quite bereft,</br>Last winter sore was shaken;</br>Of "Lamb" I've but a quarter left,</br>Nor could I save my "Bacon."
My "Hall" and "Hill" were levelled flat,</br>But "Moore" was still the cry;</br>And then, although I threw them "Sprat,"</br>They swallowed up my "Pye."
O'er every thing, however slight,</br>They seized some airy trammel;</br>They snatched my "Hogg" and "Fox" one night,</br>And pocketed my "Campbell."
And then I saw my "Crabbe" at last,</br>Like Hamlet's, backward go;</br>And as my tide was ebbing fast,</br>Of course I lost my "Rowe."
I wondered into what balloon</br>My books their course had bent;</br>And yet, with all my marvelling, soon</br>I found my "Marvell" went.
My "Mallet" served to knock me down,</br>Which makes me thus a talker;</br>And once, while I was out of town,</br>My "Johnson" proved, a Walker.
While studying o'er the fire one day</br>My "Hobbes," amidst the smoke;</br>They bore my "Colman" clean away,</br>And carried off my "Coke."
They picked my "Locke," to me far more</br>Than Bramah's patent's worth;</br>And now my losses I deplore</br>Without a "Home" on earth.
If once a book you let them lift,</br>Another they conceal;</br>For though I caught them stealing "Swift,'</br>As swiftly went my "Steele."
"Hope" is not now upon my shelf,</br>Where late he stood elated;</br>But, what is strange, my "Pope" himself</br>Is excommunicated.
My little "Suckling" in the grave</br>Is sunk, to swell the ravage;</br>And what 'twas Crusoe's fate to save</br>'Twas mine to lose — a "Savage."
Even "Glover's" works I cannot put</br>My frozen hands upon;</br>Though ever since I lost my "Foote,"</br>My "Bunyan" has been gone.
My "Hoyle" with "Cotton" went; — oppressed,</br>My "Taylor" too must fail;</br>To save my "Goldsmith" from arrest,</br>In vain I offered "Bayle."
I "Prior" sought, but could not see</br>The "Hood" so late in front;</br>And when I turned to hunt for "Lee,"</br>Oh!  where was my "Leigh Hunt?"
I tried to laugh, old Care to tickle,</br>Yet could not "Tickell" touch;</br>And then, alack!  I missed my "Mickle"—</br>And surely Mickle's much.
'Tis quite enough my griefs to feed,</br>My sorrows to excuse,</br>To think I cannot read my "Reid,"</br>Nor ever use my "Hughes."
To "West," to "South," I turn my head,</br>Exposed alike to odd jeers;</br>For since my "Roger Ascham's" fled,</br>I ask 'em for my "Rogers."
There's sure an eye that marks as well</br>The blossom s the sparrow;</br>Yet all unseen my "Lyly" fell—</br>'Twas taken in my "Barrow"
They took my "Horne" — and "Horne Tooke" too;</br>And thus my treasures flit.</br>I feel, when I would "Hazlitt" view,</br>The flames that it has lit.
My word's worth little, "Wordsworth" gone,</br>If I survive its doom;</br>How many a bard I doated on</br>Was swept off — with my "Broome!"
My classics would not quiet lie,</br>A thing so fondly hoped:</br>Like Doctor Primrose, I may cry,</br>"My 'Livy' has eloped!"
My life is wasting fast away—</br>I suffer from these shocks;</br>And though I've fixed a lock on "Gray,"</br>There's grey upon my locks.
I'm far from "Young" — am growing pale—</br>I see my "Butler" fly;</br>And when they ask about my all,</br>"'Tis 'Burton'!" I reply.
They still have made me slight returns,</br>And thus thy griefs divide;</br>For, oh!  they've cured me of my "Burns,"</br>And eased my "Akenside."
But all I think I shall not say,</br>Nor let my anger burn;</br>For as they never found me "Gay,"</br>They have not left me "Sterne."</br>
